passages.text: Jerome Powell's Jackson Hole speech has been interpreted as dovesh by the markets. The message conveyed was that the Federal Reserve will prioritise the labour market over inflation. Still if the likelihood of a 25bp cut on 17 September has risen, this also means that the next payroll data, due to be announced on 5 September, has become more important than usual. Meanwhile the inflationary pressures from tariffs are only just starting to show up, as discussed here last week (see GREED & fear - Bonds, Europe and Dr. Evil, 21 August 2025).

Wednesday was the Ganesh Chaturthi holiday in India. But it was not a happy day in the country in the specific sense that the Trump administration went ahead with the threatened \(50\%\) tariff levied on Indian goods exports, with the main exemption pharmaceuticals. This amounts to an estimated US \(55 - 60bn direct hit to the economy with the most negatively impacted sectors the likes of textiles, shoes, jewellery and gems, all of which are employment intensive.

As previously discussed here, GREED & fear would never have predicted such an outcome (see GREED & fear - Conceptual vacuum, 14 August 2025). But conversations in New Delhi at the end of last week make it clear that the tariffs are primarily the consequence of the American president's "personal pique" that he was not allowed to play a role in seeking to end the long running acrimony between India and Pakistan following the four- day military conflict between the two countries in May. India has never accepted third party intervention in its relations with Pakistan and this remains a "red line" despite the economic costs of depriving the \(47^{\text{th}}\) American president of one of his opportunities to win the Nobel Peace Prize. The other point is that no Indian government, including the current government, is going to open up agriculture to imports given the devastating impact it would have on many poor people. As noted by Jefferies' India office recently, nearly 250m farmers and related labour derive their incomes from agriculture with the sector accounting for nearly \(40\%\) of India's workforce (see Jefferies research Indo- US Tariffs Tensions Escalating, 6 August 2025).
Exhibit 1: India annualised trade with the US
Source: Ministry of Commerce and Industry, CEIC Data

That said, the word is that the two countries were very close to securing a trade deal before the conflict with Pakistan broke out triggered by the killing of 26 Indian tourists in Kashmir in April. So the draconian tariffs India now faces is the result of an unfortunate series of events, compounded by the fact that Trump has not ended the Ukraine conflict as he stated he would do. As a result, India's continuing purchases of Russian oil has again become an issue, as also previously discussed here. But the reality is that everyone in the Indian capital understands that the real issue is the refusal to allow Donald Trump's personal intervention in the Pakistan issue. This is a classic example of where the "conceptual vacuum" in Washington (see GREED & fear - Conceptual vacuum, 14 August 2025) is not in the national interest since it is surely not in America's interests to push India closer to China, a trend which was already happening with direct flights between the two countries due to resume as early as September after more than five years. Meanwhile India needs China's cheap goods, for example solar panels, with China imports into India now running at an annualised US\(118bn or 16\%\) of India's total imports and growing by \(13\%\) YoY in the 12 months to July (see Exhibit 2).
Exhibit 2: India imports from China as % of total imports (annualised)
Source: Ministry of Commerce and Industry, CEIC Data
Exhibit 3: India gross services exports
Source: RBI, Ministry of Commerce, Jefferies

Amidst the negative focus on the Trump administration's decision this week to go ahead with the tariffs, since there were definitely hopes shared by GREED & fear of a last minute U- turn by the Donald, the positive point is that the Trump administration has not yet at least focused on India's booming exports of services. This is not just IT services currently running at US\(150bn annually but also so- called global capability centres (GCCs) set

up mainly by US multinationals which base their IT infrastructure out of India and where revenues total around US \(60bn annually. This reflects the reality that when Trump talks about trade he seems to be almost solely focused on trade in goods.

As regards the Russian oil issue, Delhi is also maintaining a hard line. GREED & fear attended a public forum in the Indian capital where foreign minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar stated publicly that the largest importer of Russian oil is Europe, albeit oil which has often been refined in India, thereby highlighting European hypocrisy on this issue. He also noted, as previously discussed here, that China remains the bigger buyer of Russian oil. Meanwhile, the latest sign of Trump's desperation for a meeting with President Xi Jinping is his announcement on Monday of his sudden willingness to allow 600,000 Chinese students into American universities (see New York Times article: "Trump Says He Welcomes Chinese Students, as His Administration Blocks Them", 26 August 2025). On a related subject, GREED & fear heard an anecdote this week of an Indian woman who has recently graduated from Stanford and was offered a job by Nvidia in the US but was not given a visa.

As regards the proposed meeting with Xi, the hoped for timing seems to be around the APEC leaders' summit in Gyeongju, Korea on 31 October and 1 November. For now the Chinese president is still playing hard to get but the chances for a meeting and therefore a "deal" have to be improving so long as Trump continues to back away from the agenda of the national security lobby, as reflected in the decision to moderate America's semiconductor export controls and the decision to meet with Vladimir Putin in Alaska this month. Meanwhile it is worth noting that the Shanghai Composite Index was on Tuesday trading at its highest level since August 2015 (see Exhibit 4) and is now up \(17.4\%\) year to date in US dollar terms despite the lack of any evidence for now of a real pickup in domestic demand; though the "anti- involution" (反内卷) campaign discussed here recently has clearly been a positive for sentiment (see GREED & fear - Shakedown economics and China's focus, 31 July 2025). MSCI China is now the second best performer in the MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex- Japan universe year- to- date after Korea (see Exhibit 5). From a valuation perspective, China trades at \(12.4x\) 12- month forward earnings (see Exhibit 6). GREED & fear remains for now overweight in the Asia Pacific ex- Japan relative- return portfolio (see Exhibit 7).
Exhibit 4: Shanghai Composite Index
Exhibit 5: MSCI AC Asia Pacific country index performance year-to-date 2025
Note: Data as of 27 August 2025. Source: Datastream
Exhibit 6: MSCI China 12-month forward PE
Exhibit 7: Asia Pacific ex-Japan asset allocation

(%)MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex-Japan weightings 16-Jul-25Recommended weightings 17-Jul-25Mismatch from benchmark (ppt)Current MSCI benchmark weightings (27-Aug-25)Australia14.09.0(5.0)14.0China27.830.02.229.3Hong Kong4.15.00.94.2India17.119.01.915.8Indonesia1.12.00.91.2Korea10.413.02.610.2Malaysia1.22.00.81.2New Zealand0.40.0(0.4)0.4Philippines0.41.00.60.4Singapore3.64.00.43.7Taiwan18.812.0(6.8)18.6Thailand1.01.0(0.0)1.0Vietnam--2.02.0--Total100.0100.0--100.0
Source: Jefferies, MSCI

Returning to India, the tariff issue is all the more important because growth has already slowed, particularly nominal GDP growth which is so important for equity markets. Thus, the estimates are that nominal growth will slow to \(8\%\) YoY this quarter which is below the trend growth rate in recent years of \(10 - 12\%\) . Jefferies' India office projects nominal GDP growth to decelerate from \(10\%\) YoY in FY25 to \(8.5 - 9.0\%\) YoY in FY26 ending 31 March 2026, marking the lowest growth rate in the past two decades except Covid- related FY20 and FY21 (see Exhibit 8 and Jefferies research View from Delhi - Many Variables, 24 August 2025 and The "Nominal" Slowdown, 3 July 2025 by head of India research Mahesh Nandurkar). The main reason for this nominal slowdown is that headline CPI inflation was at an eight- year low of \(1.6\%\) YoY in July (see Exhibit 9). While WPI inflation was a negative \(0.6\%\) YoY in July.
Exhibit 8: India real GDP growth
Note: Fiscal years ending 31 March. Source: MOSPI, Jefferies
Exhibit 9: India headline CPI inflation and WPI inflation
Source: MOSPI, Ministry of Commerce and Industry, CEIC Data

Still if this is the backdrop the reason the stock market has not yet reacted more negatively of late to the \(50\%\) tariff threat, particularly consumption- related stocks, is the escalating policy response of the government. Income tax cuts were already implemented in the February budget, as discussed here previously (see GREED & fear- Tariff tantrums and out of the box, 6 February 2025). Taxpayers with an annual income of up to Rs1.2m (US\$13,700) per annum no longer pay tax, up from the previous threshold of Rs700,000/annum, while tax rates for those earning more than Rs1.2m were also lowered.

But the more positive news of late is a proposed rationalisation and simplification of GST where the current four bands (5%, 12%, 18% and 28%) will be reduced to two bands (5% and 18%). GREED & fear heard from senior officials in Delhi last week that this GST overhaul has been long in the planning, but execution has now been speeded up as a result of the Trump triggered tariff issue. The plan is for the new GST rates to be implemented before the end of September.

The view is that the fiscal loss will only be small to the central government. Indeed the hopes are that the GST cuts will be self- financing by generating more sales. A good example is air conditioners where the rate is due to be cut from 28% to 18%. The last time GST was adjusted in January 2019, albeit in only a very small way, it proved self- financing. It is worth recalling that GST, first introduced back in July 2017, has been one of many benchmark reform achievements in Narendra Modi's 11 years in government. Total GST collections have risen by an annualised 11.1% from Rs11.8tn in FY19 to Rs22.1tn in FY25 ended 31 March and are up 10.7% YoY to Rs8.2tn in April- July 2025 (see Exhibit 10). Meanwhile, if the income tax cuts primarily favour the urban middle- class since only an estimated 30m Indians pay income tax, the benefits from GST cuts are much more widely spread as a tax on spending is felt by everybody.
Exhibit 10: India total GST collections
Note: FY18 \(=\) July 2017 - March 2018. 4MFY26 \(=\) April-July 2025. Source: GST Council, Ministry of Finance, Jefferies

If these are the two major pro- consumption initiatives taken by the government so far, though more fiscal easing is likely coming, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has turned unambiguously dovesh since new governor Sanjay Malhotra took over last December. He has cut the policy repo rate by 100bp since February to 5.5% (see Exhibit 11) with the possibility of another 50bp cuts to 5% by the end of this fiscal year ending 31 March 2026, given that inflation has been running well below the central bank's formal target of 4%+/- 2% (i.e. 2- 6%). It is also the case that the impact of GST cuts will also be deflationary. Mahesh estimated in a recent report that the GST rate cut will have some dampening impact on the CPI well into 1H26 (see Jefferies research Second Leg of GST Reforms, 17 August 2025).
Exhibit 11: RBI policy repo rate and real repo rate deflated by headline and core CPI
Source: RBI,CEIC Data,Jefferies

The other point worth noting as an aside is that the RBI has just come out with a discussion paper on potentially amending the inflation target (see RBI Discussion Paper: "Review of Monetary Policy Framework", 21 August 2025). On this point, the inflation target of \(4\%\) , with a tolerance band of \(+ / - 2\%\) , was first set in 2016 for the period between 2016- 2021. Then in the first review conducted in March 2021, this target was maintained for the subsequent five years till March 2026. A second review of the target is now due by the end of March 2026. There has been some talk of moving the target from headline inflation to core given the volatility of food prices. But GREED & fear formed the impression this week that no change will be forthcoming. Core CPI inflation was \(4.1\%\) YoY in July (see Exhibit 12).
Exhibit 12: India core CPI inflation
Source: MOSPI,CEIC Data

Meanwhile, the renewed combination of fiscal and monetary easing has caused analysts to factor in a pickup in nominal growth next fiscal year, and a related pickup in earnings growth. Jefferies' India office forecasts MSCI India EPS growth to increase from \(10\%\) this fiscal year (FY26) to \(16\%\) in FY27, after slowing from \(18\%\) in FY24 (see Exhibit 13 and Jefferies research Jun'25 Or Review: Weak as expected, 18 August 2025). While nominal GDP growth is expected to rebound to \(9.5 - 10\%\) in FY27. This also explains the recent resilience of consumption stocks (see Exhibit 14), in the face of the \(50\%\) tariff threat, since domestic fund managers have this year tilted their portfolios away from cyclical capex plays to consumption plays as discussed here the last time GREED & fear was in Mumbai (see GREED & fear - DOGE and risk off in Asia, 27 February 2025).

Still if \(50\%\) tariffs do not pose a direct threat to most listed companies, they are undoubtedly a potentially massive negative for SMEs in the previously mentioned employment intensive sectors the longer they are maintained. This has the clear potential to impact negatively the likes of micro finance and consumer finance companies. In this respect, the same conclusion applies to India as it does to America, or indeed any other country. That is that the longer the tariffs are in place, the more the negative consequences will show up. On this point, Mahesh's view is that if the \(50\%\) tariffs are maintained, GDP will be impacted by an estimated 1- 1.2 percentage points with a similar cut in forecast earnings.
Exhibit 13: MSCI India EPS growth
Note: Fiscal years ending 31 March. Source: Bloomberg, Jefferies. Estimates are Jefferies estimates
Exhibit 14: Nifty India Consumption Stock Index

If this is the negative the reality in India from a stock market perspective is that the big companies in a sector are becoming ever more dominant as consolidation proceeds with the larger getting larger, be it autos, banks, cement, property or telecom.

Meanwhile, from a credit system perspective the more doveish RBI has not just been about cutting rates. There has also been significant credit easing following the credit tightening implemented by the previous governor. Examples of measures taken this year are easing of risk weightings on bank loans to NBFCs and microfinance companies, effective 1 April, while the central bank has also expressed comfort in the growth rate of banks' unsecured loans, currently running at \(8\%\) YoY compared with the \(24\%\) growth rate when the

previous RBI had raised risk weightings in November 2023 (see Exhibit 15). Another easing measure has been reducing required liquidity levels. Thus, the RBI issued in April the final revised guidelines on liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) for banks, effective April 2026. The LCR norms require banks to maintain enough stock of high- quality liquid assets (HQLA) to meet a hypothetical 30- day liquidity stress. The RBI estimates that the changes will improve the aggregate LCR of banks by around 6 percentage points, equating to a release of Rs3- 3.5tn of liquidity (see Jefferies research Final LCR Norms to Release 6ppt; a Rs10tn Positive vs First Draft, 21 April 2025 by India banking analyst Prakhar Sharma). Meanwhile, the central bank also announced in June a reduction in the cash reserve ratio (CRR) by 100bp to 3%. The reduction will be implemented in four equal tranches with the CRR reaching 3% by 29 November.
Exhibit 15: India system unsecured loan growth %YoY
Source: RBI, Jefferies
Exhibit 16: India bank credit growth and deposit growth
Source: RBI, CEIC Data

If credit easing is well under way, bank credit growth has only just started to pick up after declining from 16% YoY last June to a low of 9% in May. It was 10.2% YoY on 8 August. While deposit growth has been stable in recent months running at around 10% YoY (see Exhibit 16). Meanwhile, the view of Jefferies' India banking analyst Prakhar Sharma is that CASA ratios have bottomed and should rise as term deposits are low and liquidity levels have improved. The CASA ratio of the ten large banks under Jefferies coverage has declined from 45% in 4QFY22 to 37% in 3QFY25 and 1QFY26 ended 30 June (see Exhibit 17).
Exhibit 17: CASA ratio of ten large Indian banks under Jefferies coverage
Note: Fiscal years ending 31 March. Source: Companies, Jefferies

All of the above is why it is a reasonable assumption to bet on a pickup in nominal growth in the coming 12- 18 months, which also means that if it does not pick up there will be questions raised of whether there is something structurally amiss in terms of India's assumed trend growth rate. Meanwhile the positive point in India, relative to other large Asian economies such as China and Indonesia where nominal growth has disappointed of late, is that there has been no popular disengagement from the Indian stock market. Contrast this with Indonesia where equity mutual fund assets have declined by \(57\%\) since peaking at the end of 2018 (see Exhibit 18).
Exhibit 18: Indonesia equity mutual fund assets
Source: Financial Services Authority (OJK), Mandiri Sekuritas
Exhibit 19: India equity mutual funds net inflows
Source:Association of Mutual Funds in India

Rather, as discussed here recently (see GREED & fear - Conceptual vacuum, 14 August 2025), the culture of investing into equity mutual funds on an ongoing monthly basis remains firmly entrenched with the favoured vehicle the monthly Systematic Investment Plan (SIP). Net inflows into Indian equity mutual funds were Rs548bn in July, the highest level since October 2024 (see Exhibit 19), while SIP inflows rose by \(22\%\) YoY to a record Rs285bn in July (see Exhibit 20). GREED & fear now assumes, and indeed has done for some time, that these flows are here to stay for the foreseeable future. This is also the view, perhaps unsurprisingly, shared on the ground by the booming mutual fund industry.

Meanwhile, it is also interesting to record that Indian total mutual fund assets, as a percentage of bank deposits, have risen from \(6\%\) in March 2003 and \(10\%\) in September 2013 to \(32\%\) in July 2025 (see Exhibit 21). This is one reason why the banks' CASA ratios have been declining. It is also worth recording the increased flows of pension fund money into the stock market following recent regulatory reform. GREED & fear heard this week that the authorities have raised the proportion of assets that pension funds are allowed to hold in equities in terms of new flows from \(15\%\) to \(25\%\) . GREED & fear continues to view India as the most dynamic capital market in the world outside America despite the near term challenges.
Exhibit 20: India monthly SIP contribution (inflows)
Source:Association of Mutual Funds in India
Exhibit 21: India total mutual fund assets as \(\%\) of bank deposits
Source:Association of Mutual Funds in India (AMFI), RBI, Jefferies

Finally, one change will be made in the India long- only equity portfolio this week. The investment in Aditya Birla Real Estate will be removed and replaced by an investment in Mahindra & Mahindra (see Exhibit 22). The investment case for Mahindra & Mahindra can be found in a just published sector report by Jefferies' India auto and metal analyst Nitij Mangal (see India Auto & Auto Parts - Earnings Outlook Brightens on GST Optimism, 27 August 2025). Aditya Birla Real Estate is up \(183\%\) since inception on 1 July 2021 when it was called Century Textiles.
Exhibit 22: India long-only equity portfolio

Benchmark index: MSCI India; Rationale: Portfolio stocks designed to increase in value; Methodology: Fundamental analysis of coverage stocks and the strategist's view of respective sectors; Type of Model Portfolio: India-listed stocks across all sectors; Investment Horizon: Aim is to deliver outperformance over one-year time-frame; Investment Objective: The aim is to achieve long-term absolute-return performance; Launch date: 1 July 2021; Updated on 28 August 2025. The portfolio undergoes periodical review linked to either macro events (such as government budget, major central bank policy changes etc.) and stock specific events (analyst reco change, price movement etc.); Risks: OwT stance on certain stocks can impact portfolio performance if these stocks UPF, and vice versa.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus\) 20\% \(or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/rowth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
